issues.description: The problem statement and the template expect a no-argument messageOnRide() method (returns String) on the Rideable interface and in usages (e.g., Main calls r.messageOnRide()). However, the solution implements Rideable.messageOnRide(int speed) (takes an int parameter) and updates Pig and Seal to implement messageOnRide(int). This parameter mismatch means students implementing the exercise according to the problem/template will produce a different signature than the provided solution, and the solution's Main (which calls messageOnRide() with no argument) is also inconsistent with its own Rideable implementation. This will confuse students and can cause compilation/signature conflicts when comparing their implementation to the solution or when reusing the provided Main code.
issues.suggested_fix:
Make the Rideable.messageOnRide signature consistent across all artifacts. Two possible fixes (choose one to restore consistency):

1) Align with the problem statement and template: change Rideable.messageOnRide to have no parameters (String messageOnRide()), and update Pig and Seal to implement messageOnRide() returning "Riding on [Animal Type] [name]". Also ensure solution Main (and any example usage) calls messageOnRide() with no arguments.

2) If an integer speed parameter is desired pedagogically, update the problem statement, UML, and template Main to document and call messageOnRide(int speed) (and adjust example output expectations), so students implement the parameterized method. Update the example usage in Main accordingly.

Option 1 is the minimal change to match the current problem description and template and will avoid confusing students comparing to the solution.

issues.description: The exercise specification and template expect a Rideable.messageOnRide() method with signature messageOnRide():String (no parameters) and return value "Riding on [Animal Type] [name]". The solution repository changes this contract: Rideable.messageOnRide(int speed) requires an int parameter and implementations (Pig, Seal) return strings containing the speed ("Riding on X at Y mph"). This divergence changes the intended API, causes the commented test/example code in Main (and the template) to be incompatible with the solution, and forces students to reconcile two different method signatures/behaviors for the same conceptual operation (riding an animal).
issues.suggested_fix: Make the Rideable API consistent across artifacts. Either (A) restore the no-argument method as specified in the problem/template: change Rideable to declare String messageOnRide(); and update Pig and Seal to implement messageOnRide() returning exactly "Riding on [Animal Type] [name]" (remove the speed parameter and the "at X mph" text), or (B) update the problem statement and template Main to require and demonstrate messageOnRide(int speed) and specify the expected string format including the speed. Option A is recommended to match the original exercise text and template example code.
